pages.home: EthioDirect â€” Coffee That Was Waiting for You
pages.blog_subtitle: Dive into the world of specialty coffee: from Ethiopian plantations to your cup

sidamo_guide.title: Sidamo: Classic Ethiopian Coffee
sidamo_guide.subtitle: Everything about Ethiopia's most popular coffee production region and its unique terroir.
sidamo_guide.intro: Sidamo is one of Ethiopia's largest and most famous coffee regions. Most of Ethiopia's exported coffee is produced here.
sidamo_guide.geography_p1: Sidamo (or Sidama) is a region in the Rift Valley in southern Ethiopia. Interestingly, Yirgacheffe is technically part of Sidamo but has gained its own status due to its unique flavor.
sidamo_guide.taste_value: milk chocolate, almond, soft citrus acidity
sidamo_guide.why_universal_desc: â€” suitable for both espresso and filter
sidamo_guide.why_balance_desc: â€” not too acidic, not too bitter
sidamo_guide.how_brew_intro: Sidamo is one of the most versatile coffees. It works great with:
sidamo_guide.brew_espresso_desc: â€” medium roast, bright crema, chocolate flavor
sidamo_guide.brew_v60_desc: â€” light roast, reveals fruity notes
sidamo_guide.our_sidamo_text: We work with cooperatives in the Bensa area â€” one of the best sub-regions of Sidamo. Our coffee undergoes washed processing and has a score of 85 SCA points.
sidamo_guide.cta_text: Order authentic coffee from the Sidamo region
sidamo_guide.p_region: Sidamo is located in southern Ethiopia, at 1500-2200 meters elevation. The region has an ideal climate for growing Arabica: sufficient rainfall, moderate temperatures, and fertile soils.
sidamo_guide.p_taste: Sidamo coffee is known for its balanced taste with notes of berries, chocolate, and spices. Acidity ranges from moderate to bright, body is medium.

yirgacheffe_region.title: Yirgacheffe: The Pearl of Ethiopian Coffee
yirgacheffe_region.subtitle: Legendary region with floral taste
yirgacheffe_region.intro: Yirgacheffe is not just a region name, it's a synonym for the most elegant coffee in the world. Floral, citrus notes and incredible cup clarity have made this variety iconic.
yirgacheffe_region.geography_p1: Yirgacheffe is a small district within the Sidamo region in southern Ethiopia. Thanks to its unique microclimate and ideal altitude (1750-2200 m), coffee here acquires a special character.

ethiopia_coffee_origin.title: Ethiopia â€” The Birthplace of Coffee
ethiopia_coffee_origin.subtitle: History, legends and uniqueness
ethiopia_coffee_origin.intro: Ethiopia is the only country where coffee grows naturally in the wild. It was here that coffee was discovered over 1000 years ago thanks to the legendary shepherd Kaldi.
ethiopia_coffee_origin.legend_p1: According to legend, the shepherd Kaldi noticed that his goats became energetic after eating red berries from a certain bush. He told the monks about it, and thus began the history of coffee.
ethiopia_coffee_origin.cta_text: From the birthplace of coffee â€” to your cup

what_is_specialty.title: What is Specialty Coffee and Why Does It Cost More
what_is_specialty.subtitle: Understanding how specialty coffee differs from regular coffee, how professionals grade it, and why it's worth every penny.
what_is_specialty.intro: If you've ever wondered why one bag of coffee costs 100 hryvnias while another costs 400, the answer lies in the concept of specialty coffee. This isn't just a marketing buzzword â€” behind it stands a rigorous grading system, decades of expertise, and a genuine passion for quality.
what_is_specialty.definition: Specialty coffee is coffee that has scored 80 points or higher on the SCA 100-point scale.
what_is_specialty.quote1: "Specialty coffee is about 3% of all coffee produced worldwide. It's like comparing table wine to Grand Cru."
what_is_specialty.grading_intro: Coffee grading is a real science. Certified Q-graders analyze beans across 11 criteria.
what_is_specialty.why_expensive_title: Why is Specialty Coffee More Expensive?
what_is_specialty.recognize_title: How to Recognize Real Specialty Coffee
what_is_specialty.cta_title: Ready to Try Real Specialty Coffee?
what_is_specialty.cta_text: Order our bestseller â€” Yirgacheffe with floral and citrus notes
what_is_specialty.p_history: The term "specialty coffee" officially appeared in 1974 when Erna Knutsen, one of the pioneers of the coffee industry, first used it to describe coffee of the highest quality. Since then, the concept has evolved and today has a clear definition.
what_is_specialty.p_definition: Specialty coffee is coffee that has scored 80 points or higher on the Specialty Coffee Association (SCA) 100-point scale. For comparison: regular commercial coffee rarely exceeds 70 points, and anything below 60 is considered poor quality.
what_is_specialty.p_grading_intro: Coffee grading is a real science. Certified Q-graders (coffee experts) analyze beans across 11 criteria:
what_is_specialty.criteria_aroma: Aroma â€” smell of dry and wet beans
what_is_specialty.criteria_aftertaste: Aftertaste â€” duration and quality of taste
what_is_specialty.criteria_sweetness: Sweetness â€” natural sweetness of the bean
what_is_specialty.p_grading_note: Each criterion is scored from 6 to 10 points. For beans to achieve specialty status, they must have no more than 5 defects per 350 grams during visual inspection.
what_is_specialty.h2_why_expensive: Why is Specialty Coffee More Expensive?
what_is_specialty.p_expensive_intro: The high price of specialty coffee isn't just marketing markup. Behind it are real costs at every stage:
what_is_specialty.p_terroir: The best coffee grows at 1800-2200 meters above sea level, in tropical climates with distinct seasons. These conditions exist in only a few regions worldwide, and Ethiopia is one of them.
what_is_specialty.p_harvest: Unlike commercial coffee, which is often machine-harvested, specialty cherries are picked by hand, selecting only ripe ones. This is 10 times slower but guarantees quality.
what_is_specialty.p_processing: Every stage â€” from fermentation to drying â€” is controlled manually. Natural processing (when the cherry dries whole) can take up to 4 weeks.
what_is_specialty.p_roasting: Specialty coffee has optimal taste within 2-4 weeks after roasting. At EthioDirect, we roast to order so you receive the freshest product.
what_is_specialty.p_fairtrade: Farmers producing specialty coffee receive fair prices â€” often 2-3 times higher than market rate. This allows them to invest in quality improvement.
what_is_specialty.h2_recognize: How to Recognize Real Specialty Coffee
what_is_specialty.p_recognize_intro: Unfortunately, not everything labeled "premium" or "specialty" on supermarket shelves actually is. Here's what to look for:
what_is_specialty.tip_date: Roast Date â€” should be printed, not "best before"
what_is_specialty.tip_origin: Origin â€” region specified, even better â€” farm name
what_is_specialty.tip_sca: SCA Score â€” if 80+ points are indicated, it's a good sign
what_is_specialty.tip_profile: Flavor Profile â€” specific notes described (not just "aromatic")
what_is_specialty.tip_volume: Small Volume â€” specialty is rarely sold in 1kg packages
what_is_specialty.h2_worth_it: Is It Worth the Extra Cost?
what_is_specialty.p_worth_intro: If you drink coffee just for morning caffeine â€” maybe not. But if coffee for you is pleasure, ritual, a moment of enjoyment â€” absolutely yes.
what_is_specialty.p_worth_flavors: Specialty coffee will open a world of flavors you never suspected: from floral jasmine notes to berry sweetness of blueberry, from citrus freshness to chocolate depth. It's an entirely different experience.
what_is_specialty.quote2: "When I first tried real Ethiopian Yirgacheffe, I realized that until then I hadn't been drinking coffee â€” just bitter caffeinated liquid."
what_is_specialty.p_conclusion: Try it at least once â€” and you'll understand what we're talking about. And our 85+ point coffee is a perfect start to this journey.

light_vs_dark_roast.title: Light vs Dark Roast
light_vs_dark_roast.subtitle: How roast level affects taste
light_vs_dark_roast.intro: Roasting is the key stage that determines the character of coffee. Light roast reveals terroir and acidity, dark adds body and bitterness.
light_vs_dark_roast.light_desc: Preserves the original bean flavor, emphasizes fruity and floral notes. Ideal for Specialty coffee.
light_vs_dark_roast.dark_desc: Adds caramel, chocolate notes. Less acidity, more bitterness. Classic for espresso.

water_for_coffee.title: What Water Do You Need for Perfect Coffee?
water_for_coffee.subtitle: 98% of your cup is water. Understanding why it matters and which to choose.
water_for_coffee.intro: Water is 98% of your coffee cup. Even the best beans won't reach their potential with the wrong water.
water_for_coffee.p_why: Water is the solvent that extracts flavor compounds from coffee. Too soft water gives weak extraction, too hard â€” excessive bitterness.
water_for_coffee.p_ideal: Per SCA recommendations: TDS (total dissolved solids) 75-250 ppm, pH 6.5-7.5. Simplest option â€” filtered water or quality bottled water.
water_for_coffee.p_avoid: Distilled water â€” too soft. Tap water (in most cities) â€” contains chlorine and is too hard. High-mineral water â€” will overpower coffee taste.

yirgacheffe.title: Yirgacheffe: The Gem of Ethiopian Coffee
yirgacheffe.subtitle: Why this region produces one of the world's most expensive coffees and what flavors to look for.
yirgacheffe.intro: Yirgacheffe (pronounced "Yeer-ga-chef-eh") is a legendary region in southern Ethiopia that produces one of the world's most recognizable coffees.
yirgacheffe.location_text: Yirgacheffe is a small town and surrounding region in the Gedeo zone, in the Sidamo region (SNNPR) of southern Ethiopia. Altitude â€” 1700-2200 meters above sea level, creating ideal conditions for slow berry ripening.
yirgacheffe.terroir_text: Volcanic soils rich in minerals, even climate with rainy seasons, high altitude â€” all this creates a unique "terroir", similar to famous wine regions.
yirgacheffe.genetics_text: A unique subspecies of Arabica grows here â€” Ethiopian Heirloom. This is not a cultivated variety, but wild varieties that have been preserved for millennia.
yirgacheffe.processing_text: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is processed using the washed method, which emphasizes its clarity and floral notes. Naturally processed is rarer but has an even more intense berry flavor.
yirgacheffe.quote: "Yirgacheffe is not just coffee. It's perfume in a cup. Close your eyes â€” and you're in a flower garden."
yirgacheffe.roast_value: only light or very light medium
yirgacheffe.not_rec_value: Turkish or espresso â€” will overshadow delicate notes
yirgacheffe.our_text: We work directly with a cooperative in the Kochere region (one of the best micro-regions of Yirgacheffe). Our coffee has a score of 88 SCA points and a bright profile: jasmine, bergamot, lemon zest.
yirgacheffe.p_geography: The region is located at 1700-2200 meters above sea level, in the Gedeo zone. These are ideal conditions for Arabica: cool nights, moderate days, adequate rainfall, and rich volcanic soils.
yirgacheffe.p_taste: Yirgacheffe is famous for its unique taste: bright floral notes (jasmine, bergamot), citrus acidity (lemon, orange), tea-like body, and a long sweet aftertaste.
yirgacheffe.p_processing: Traditionally, Yirgacheffe is washed, giving a clean, bright taste. But lately, natural processing is becoming more popular â€” it adds sweetness and berry notes.

ethiopia_origin.title: Ethiopia â€” The Birthplace of Coffee: The Legend of Kaldi
ethiopia_origin.subtitle: The story of how a goatherd accidentally discovered the magic of coffee berries over 1000 years ago.
ethiopia_origin.intro: Every cup of coffee begins in Ethiopia. This isn't just a nice phrase â€” it's a historical fact. Right here, in the mountains of East Africa, more than a thousand years ago, humanity first discovered the invigorating effects of coffee berries.
ethiopia_origin.legend_p1: In the 9th century, goatherd Kaldi noticed: his goats, after eating red berries from an unknown bush, became extremely energetic â€” jumping and unable to sleep.
ethiopia_origin.quote1: "The goats danced in the moonlight. Kaldi understood â€” these berries have magical power."
ethiopia_origin.legend_p2: Kaldi tried the berries himself and felt a surge of energy. He took them to a monastery, where the monks first threw them into the fire. But the incredible aroma of the roasted beans made them reconsider â€” thus the first coffee drink was born.
ethiopia_origin.century16_text: â€” became popular in the Ottoman Empire
ethiopia_origin.century18_text: â€” spread to colonies and became a global commodity
ethiopia_origin.diversity_text: over 10,000 Arabica varieties â€” more than all other countries combined.
ethiopia_origin.traditions_text: most coffee is grown in the shade of natural forest, without chemicals.
ethiopia_origin.quote2: "In Ethiopia they say: 'Buna dabo naw' â€” 'Coffee is our bread'."
ethiopia_origin.h2_legend: The Legend of Kaldi the Goatherd
ethiopia_origin.p_legend1: The most famous legend about coffee's origin tells of an Ethiopian goatherd named Kaldi, who lived around the 9th century AD.
ethiopia_origin.p_legend2: One day, Kaldi noticed that his goats became extraordinarily energetic and active after eating red berries from an unknown bush. They jumped, ran, and couldn't calm down until late at night.
ethiopia_origin.p_legend3: The curious shepherd decided to try the berries himself. Feeling a surge of energy, he brought his discovery to the local monastery.
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery1: The monks were initially skeptical of the discovery. According to one version, the abbot even threw the berries into the fire, calling them "the devil's work."
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery2: But when the berries began to roast, the room filled with an incredible aroma. The monks retrieved the roasted beans, ground them, and poured hot water over them â€” thus was born the first coffee drink.
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery3: The monks quickly appreciated the practical benefit: the drink helped them stay awake during long night prayers.
ethiopia_origin.p_spread1: Over the following centuries, coffee spread first to the Arabian Peninsula, then to Turkey, Venice, and the rest of Europe.
ethiopia_origin.p_spread2: But Ethiopia remains unique â€” it's the only country in the world where coffee grows wild. Here you can find thousands of varieties that exist nowhere else.
ethiopia_origin.p_today1: Ethiopia is the fifth-largest coffee producer in the world and first in Africa. Coffee provides about 60% of the country's export revenue.
ethiopia_origin.p_today2: The most famous production regions: Yirgacheffe, Sidamo, Guji, Harrar, Limu. Each has a unique terroir and flavor profile.
ethiopia_origin.p_ceremony: In Ethiopia, coffee is more than a drink. The traditional coffee ceremony ("Buna") can last for hours and is an important part of social life. Beans are roasted, ground, and brewed right before guests.
ethiopia_origin.cta_text: Order authentic Ethiopian coffee from Yirgacheffe and Sidamo regions

light_vs_dark.title: Light or Dark Roast: What to Choose?
light_vs_dark.subtitle: Comparing flavor profiles, caffeine levels, and recommendations for different brewing methods.
light_vs_dark.intro: One of the most common questions from buyers: which roast is better â€” light or dark? Short answer: it depends on your preferences. Long answer â€” in this article.
light_vs_dark.process_text: Roasting is the thermal processing of green beans at 180-230Â°C.
light_vs_dark.caffeine_myth_text: Many believe that dark roast is "stronger" and contains more caffeine. This is actually a myth!
light_vs_dark.cta_text: Our catalog has coffee from light to dark roast
light_vs_dark.p_process: Roasting is the thermal processing of green coffee beans at 180-230Â°C. During this process, the bean undergoes chemical reactions that form the taste, aroma, and color of coffee.
light_vs_dark.p_light: The bean is roasted until the first "crack" â€” a characteristic sound when the bean cracks from internal pressure. Color â€” light brown.
light_vs_dark.p_medium: Roasting continues slightly longer after the first crack. Color â€” rich brown. This is the most popular choice for most consumers.
light_vs_dark.p_dark: Roasting continues until the second crack and beyond. Color â€” dark brown to almost black, often with an oily surface.
light_vs_dark.p_caffeine: Many believe that dark roast is "stronger" and contains more caffeine. Actually, this is a myth! The caffeine content is almost the same across all roasts, and sometimes light roast even contains slightly more.
light_vs_dark.p_choose: For alternative methods (V60, Aeropress) light roast works better. For espresso â€” medium or dark. For Turkish coffee â€” dark. But most importantly â€” experiment!

natural_vs_washed.title: Natural vs Washed: How Processing Affects Taste
natural_vs_washed.subtitle: The difference between dry and washed processing and why it matters for your cup.
natural_vs_washed.intro: Processing is one of the key factors determining your coffee's taste. Let's explore how the two main methods differ.
natural_vs_washed.natural_text: Cherries are dried whole under the sun for 2-4 weeks. The pulp ferments and imparts sweetness to the bean.
natural_vs_washed.washed_text: Pulp is removed immediately, beans ferment in water. Clean, bright taste.
natural_vs_washed.honey_text: Partial pulp removal. Balance between natural and washed.
natural_vs_washed.p_washed: In washed processing, the fruit pulp is removed immediately after harvesting. The bean undergoes fermentation in water, then is washed and dried. Result: clean, bright taste with clear acidity.
natural_vs_washed.p_natural: In natural processing, the cherry dries whole â€” with the pulp. The process takes 2-4 weeks. Result: rich, sweet taste with fruity and berry notes.
natural_vs_washed.p_difference: Washed coffee is more "clean" with clear notes. Natural is more "wild" with deep fruity flavors. Both methods have their fans.

grinder_guide.title: How to Choose a Coffee Grinder: Complete Beginner's Guide
grinder_guide.subtitle: Burr or blade? Manual or electric? Understanding grinder types and their advantages.
grinder_guide.intro: A grinder is perhaps the most important investment for a home barista. Freshly ground coffee is always better than pre-ground.
grinder_guide.p_blade: Blade grinders â€” cheapest, but give uneven grind. Not recommended for specialty coffee.
grinder_guide.p_burr: Burr grinders â€” come in flat and conical. Give even grind needed for proper extraction.
grinder_guide.p_manual: Manual â€” cheaper, quiet, compact. Downside: need to crank 1-2 minutes. Electric â€” fast and convenient, but more expensive.
grinder_guide.p_recommend: To start: manual Timemore C2 or Hario Skerton. For espresso: Baratza Encore or 1Zpresso JX-Pro.
grinder_guide.h2_1: Why Do You Need a Grinder?

aeropress_recipes.title: 3 Aeropress Recipes from Champions
aeropress_recipes.subtitle: Proven recipes from championship winners for the perfect cup at home.
aeropress_recipes.intro: Aeropress is one of the most versatile brewing methods. Here are three recipes from world championship winners.
aeropress_recipes.p_classic: 15g coffee, 200ml water 85Â°C. Medium grind. Time: 1:30. Pour, stir, press.
aeropress_recipes.p_inverted: Aeropress inverted. 17g coffee, 220ml water 92Â°C. Steep 2 minutes, flip, press.
aeropress_recipes.p_champion: 12g coffee, 200ml water 78Â°C. Very fine grind. Time: 2:00. Result: rich, sweet taste.

cold_brew_recipe.title: Cold Brew at Home: Simple Recipe for 5 Liters
cold_brew_recipe.subtitle: How to make refreshing cold-brewed coffee without special equipment.
cold_brew_recipe.intro: Cold brew is the perfect drink for hot days. It's smooth, sweet, and almost bitter-free. Best of all â€” it's easy to make at home.
cold_brew_recipe.p_what: Cold brew is coffee brewed with cold water for 12-24 hours. Unlike iced coffee (hot coffee with ice), cold brew is never heated.
cold_brew_recipe.p_ratio: Ratio: 1:8 (100g coffee to 800ml water). Coarse grind, like for French press.
cold_brew_recipe.p_steps: Mix coffee with cold water in a jar. Leave in fridge for 12-24 hours. Strain through filter. Concentrate can be diluted with water/milk 1:1.
cold_brew_recipe.p_tips: Use coffees with fruity notes â€” they shine in cold brew. Store concentrate up to 2 weeks in fridge.

espresso_mistakes.title: 7 Mistakes When Making Espresso at Home
espresso_mistakes.subtitle: Why is your espresso bitter or sour? Breaking down common mistakes and how to avoid them.
espresso_mistakes.intro: Buying an espresso machine is just the start of the journey to perfect espresso. Here are the most common mistakes preventing coffee enjoyment.
espresso_mistakes.p_grind: Too coarse â€” watery, sour shot. Too fine â€” bitter, slow. Experiment!
espresso_mistakes.p_dose: Use scales! Standard dose â€” 18-20g coffee for a double shot.
espresso_mistakes.p_temp: Ideal: 92-96Â°C. Warm up the machine at least 15 minutes before first shot.
espresso_mistakes.p_fresh: Espresso is best from coffee 7-21 days after roasting. Fresh roast produces too much gas.
espresso_mistakes.p_tamp: Tamp evenly with ~15 kg pressure. Uneven tamping = uneven extraction.
espresso_mistakes.p_clean: Clean the group after every shot. Old oils = bitter taste.

turka_recipe.title: Turkish Coffee: Secrets of Perfect Cezve
turka_recipe.subtitle: A traditional brewing method preserved through centuries. Step-by-step recipe.
turka_recipe.intro: Coffee in a cezve (ibrik) is the oldest brewing method, over 500 years old. Here's how to make it properly.
turka_recipe.p_equipment: Cezve (copper is best), very finely ground coffee, cold water, sand or low heat.
turka_recipe.p_step1: 7g coffee per 60ml cold water. Grind â€” powder-fine, finer than espresso.
turka_recipe.p_step2: Mix coffee with cold water in cezve. Add sugar if desired.
turka_recipe.p_step3: Heat slowly on lowest flame. Never boil!
turka_recipe.p_step4: When foam starts to rise â€” remove from heat. Repeat 2-3 times for richness.
turka_recipe.p_tips: Don't stir after heating starts. Use dark roast. Serve with a glass of cold water.

how_to_brew_v60.title: Perfect V60: Step-by-Step Recipe from a Barista
how_to_brew_v60.subtitle: Detailed instructions for brewing coffee with pour-over. Ratios, temperature, pouring technique.
how_to_brew_v60.intro: V60 is one of the most popular filter coffee brewing methods. Here's a step-by-step recipe used by professional baristas.
how_to_brew_v60.p_equipment: V60 dripper, paper filters, coffee grinder, gooseneck kettle, scale, timer, 15g coffee, 250ml water (94Â°C).
how_to_brew_v60.p_ratio: Classic V60 ratio: 1:16.6 (15g coffee to 250ml water). For stronger coffee use 1:15, for lighter â€” 1:17.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step1: Rinse the filter with hot water. This removes paper taste and preheats the dripper.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step2: Add ground coffee (medium-fine, like sea salt) and make a well in the center.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step3: Start with pre-infusion: pour 30ml water, wait 30-45 seconds while coffee "blooms."
how_to_brew_v60.p_step4: Continue pouring water in circles, from center to edges. Total brew time: 2:30-3:00.
how_to_brew_v60.cta_text: We recommend light roast for the best flavor

coffee_storage.title: How to Store Coffee Properly: 5 Key Rules
coffee_storage.subtitle: Enemies of coffee freshness and simple rules to preserve aroma longer.
coffee_storage.intro: Even the best coffee can lose its flavor due to improper storage. Here are 5 key rules to follow.
coffee_storage.p_smells: Foreign odors â€” coffee easily absorbs them
coffee_storage.p_tips: Keep coffee in airtight packaging, in a dark cool place. Not in the fridge! Ground coffee keeps 2 weeks, beans â€” up to a month after roasting.
coffee_storage.cta_text: We roast to order â€” you'll receive the freshest coffee
coffee_storage.h2_4: Can You Store in the Fridge?

caffeine_myths.title: 5 Caffeine Myths Everyone Believes
caffeine_myths.subtitle: Is it true that dark roast has more caffeine? Debunking popular myths.
caffeine_myths.intro: There are many myths around caffeine. Let's figure out what's true and what's not.
caffeine_myths.p_myth1: FALSE. Caffeine content is almost the same across all roasts. "Strength" refers to flavor, not caffeine.
caffeine_myths.h2_myth2: Myth 2: Espresso Has the Most Caffeine
caffeine_myths.p_myth2: PARTLY TRUE. Per milliliter â€” yes. But a cup of filter coffee has more caffeine overall due to larger volume.
caffeine_myths.p_myth3: FALSE. Coffee is 98% water and is a mild diuretic. It doesn't dehydrate with normal consumption.
caffeine_myths.p_myth4: PARTLY TRUE. Tolerance develops, but it's not addiction in the medical sense. Withdrawal is mild discomfort for 1-2 days.
caffeine_myths.p_myth5: FALSE. Decaf contains 2-15 mg caffeine per cup (regular has 80-100 mg).
caffeine_myths.h3_2: Myth 2: Espresso Has the Most Caffeine

arabica_vs_robusta.title: Arabica vs Robusta: Complete Guide
arabica_vs_robusta.intro: "100% Arabica" â€” you've seen this on every other bag of coffee. But what does it actually mean? And why does Robusta have such a bad reputation?
arabica_vs_robusta.when_choose_title: When to Choose Arabica vs Robusta?
arabica_vs_robusta.cta_text: We work only with 100% premium Arabica

bean_to_cup.title: Coffee Bean Journey: From Farm to Cup
bean_to_cup.intro: Every cup of coffee is the result of a long journey. From planting to roasting, each stage affects the taste.
